newsitem.title: USA: Chino copper talks adjourned, set to resume in Nov.
newsitem.headline: Chino copper talks adjourned, set to resume in Nov.

text.p: Labor talks at Phelps Dodge Corp's Chino mine in New Mexico on Oct 24 and 25 ended without agreement, but a further round was tentatively scheduled early next month, the company said.
The company met with labor union representatives in a bid to end the four-month deadlock. Unionized employees have been working without contract since the previous three-year deal expired June 30.
Phelps' spokeswoman Sue Suver said last week's meeting was businesslike.
"The discussions were productive and the unions indicated they may want to come back for further discussions on or about Nov 7," Suver said.
"They discussed a lot of different issues in the offer that we presented to them," Suver added.
Manny Armenta, an organizer for the USWA, confirmed that tentative talks were scheduled for November 7 through 9 after the unions made proposals to the company last week.
Phelps presented its final offer to the unions late August and Suver said no amendments were made to that offer during last week's talks.

"But there is a slowdown in production definitely. The people are not content because they felt other companies have reached an agreement, like ASARCO and Kennecott and they got pretty decent packages," Armenta said.
"The mood is low and the tensions are very high," Armenta added.
Suver said Chino was working normally.
Phelps is offering a pay freeze while contracts ratified recently at an ASARCO location, and at Kennecott Utah Copper Corp last week, included a pay hike.
Chino produced 170,000 tonnnes of contained copper in 1995.
